items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  District Policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (current bid limit is $81,000) should have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $750, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contract and purchase orders for the period of January 10, 2012 through February 9, 2012 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
Per Sections 20118 and 20652 of the California Public Contract Code, the governing board of any community college district may award a contract without advertising for bids when the Board has determined it to be in the best interest of the District. The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation or agency.
	 
On January 11, 2011, the Board of Trustees authorized the award of a contract without advertising for bids by determining it was in the best interest of the District to 'piggyback' on the contract between The Cooperative Purchasing Network (TCPN) and Office Depot as the primary supplier of the District's office supplies. The agreement enabled the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on office supplies through February 28, 2012. This contract has been extended until February 28, 2015.
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees continue the contract without advertising for bids by determining it is in the best interest of the District to 'piggyback' on an already competitively-bid contract between TCPN and Office Depot as the primary supplier of the District's office supplies. This will enable the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on office supplies through February 28, 2015.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to continue to 'piggyback' on a contract with Office Depot.

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the amendment to the 2011-2012 WIA Workshops contract.
Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide a wide variety of job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers at multiple locations including the three primary work2future One-Stops (Campbell, Gilroy and San Jose).  For the program year 2011-2012, work2future awarded Workforce Institute an initial contract of $1,053,300 for job readiness workshop services, which was approved by the Board of Trustees on August 9, 2011.   Work2future has requested additional job readiness and career enhancement workshops, Next Jobs online services, and online training to individuals affected by the Cisco mass layoff and the Solyndra closure in summer 2011 and is amending the original contract by adding $580,000 in new funding for a new contract total of $1,633,300.  To provide the additional services as requested, the Independent Contractor Agreements will be increased as follows:
	 
				Subcontractor
				Service Provided
				Previous Allotment
				Increase
				Total Allotment
				Next Jobs
				Online Career Enhancements

				$63,000

items.item_details:
In November 2011, the Board approved an update to the San Jose City College Master Plans that identified the replacement of the physical education and fitness center facilities. The District issued a Request for Proposal (RFP) for Professional Design Services for these projects. 
	 
Through this RFP process, SJCC has selected to move forward with design services through the design development stage of the project with LPAS architecture. This project is the last project funded in the Measure G 2004 Bond Series for San Jose City College and will complete this bond for the college.

items.item_details:
In May 2009, the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District issued $46,775,000 of taxable Other Post Employment Benefit Bonds (OPEB) to refund the District’s liability for retiree benefits and to provide general fund relief.  The bonds were placed with U.S. Bank for three years at a fixed interest rate of 4.62% coming due May 14, 2012.  The District entered into a forward starting swap with the plan that on May 14, 2012, the bonds will be refunded into a variable rate interest rate mode and combined with the swap, create a synthetic fixed rate.
	 
At the February 14, 2012 Board of Trustees meeting Piper Jaffrey, the District’s investment banking/underwriting firm, presented two financing options for the OPEB bonds that mature on May 14, 2012.  The Board of Trustees approved a resolution to proceed to restructure and refund the OPEB bonds to lock in low interest rates, provide a longer term solution for the OPEB program, and minimize the effect on the District's general fund. 
	 
The bonds will be privately placed with First Republic Bank in a variable interest rate mode for a maximum period of 15 years, terminating May 1, 2027.  The District has the option to prepay the bonds after five years. The interest rate will be based on three month LIBOR plus 100 basis points and be due on the first day of each month. The District will pay a fixed swap rate of $4.239% and 1.00% to First Republic Bank with an all interest rate of 5.239%. The current estimate of cost of issuance is $750,000 to be included in the bond proceeds.  The estimated annual debt service is $2.49 million for fiscal year 2013/2022 and $5.51 million for years 2023 through 2044. This represents a 3.25% escalation from 2023/2044.  
	 
The District is currently rated Aa1 by Moody’s and AA- by Standard and Poor’s. If the District’s general obligation bond rating is downgraded, there is a 25 basis point increase to the pricing spread for each level of downgrade below Aa2 and AA-. This penalty is reversed for each upgrade by a rating agency.  The District covenants to maintain a rating of no lower than A3 by Moody’s and A- by Standard and Poor’s.
	 
Once approval is received from the Board of Trustees, the Finance Team will move into action immediately to lock down an interest rate. It will then take about 30-60 days to complete the legal paperwork commemorating the OPEB Bond restructuring.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution #031312-2, authorizing the sale of taxable OPEB bonds, Series B, approving legal documents, and authorizing certain other actions.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT Board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. Although the election announcement and call for nominations indicated that there are seven seats to be filled, there are now eight seats due to the recent resignation from the board by Trustee Larwood.
	 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the eight vacancies on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The eight candidates who receive the most votes will serve three-year terms. In the event of a tie vote for the last position to be filled, the CCCT board will vote to break the tie.
	 
The eleven trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the enclosed sheet in the order of the Secretary of State's random drawing. An official ballot for the election is also enclosed in this mailing to each community college district, as well as copies of the statement of candidacy and biographic sketch form of each of the eleven candidates.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees choose 8 of 11 candidates to serve on the CCCT Board.

items.item_details:
Each local Board of Trustees may forward to the California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office the name of one nominee for the California Community College Classified Employees of the Year sponsored by the California Community Colleges Board of Governors and the Foundation for California Community Colleges and funded by the Foundation for California Community Colleges. Using the guidelines established by the State Chancellor's Office, the CSEA has selected a nominee for this award.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept Gary Cooper as the CSEA nominee as a recipient of the California Community Colleges Classified Employees award.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept Gary Cooper as the CSEA nominee for the California Community Colleges Classified Employees of the Year for submittal to the State Chancellor's Office.

items.item_details:
INFORMATION  ITEMS
Program Update / Project Highlights
At the January 24th, 2012 Board of Trustees’ meeting a facilities and capital bonds study session was held to update the Board on the status and progress of the Measure I-1998 and Measure G-2004 Bond Programs and to highlight the progress of implementation activities for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program.
The presentation will consist of the attached PowerPoint slides.  This informational item is to follow-up on key issues discussed at the study session relative to:
Website Updates
Change Order – Best Practices
Design Presentations
Outreach Program: Open House
Project Delivery Methods
Monthly Measure G-2010 Summary Report
Monthly Measure G-2010 Summary Report - inception through February 29, 2012
As per our discussions at the February workshop with the Board, attached please find the new Measure G - 2010 Summary Report.  This report represents the Measure G-2010 projects from inception through February 29, 2012, with financial data reconciled through December 31, 2011.
ACTION  ITEMS
Contracts
Civil Engineering Master Agreements for Measure G-2010 Projects
In November, 2011 the Board approved an update to the San Jose City College and the Evergreen Valley College Master Plan that identified projects that will require direct contracting to civil engineers.  In keeping with the updated Master Plan, the District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Professional Civil Engineering Services to perform various tasks under direct contract to the District on a work-order basis for various Measure G-2010 projects.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to 12 minority and woman-owned small disadvantaged businesses.
	 
On February 16, 2012, the District received a Statement of Qualifications (SOQ) from nine (9) firms in response to the RFQ.  A District Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District and each college reviewed each SOQ.  The panel members were Carlos Marques (Purchasing), Gail Mathis (Facilities), Rudy Nasol (SJCC) and Henry Gee (EVC).  The Panel discussed the SOQ’s received and ranked the firms.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected four (4) firms to be offered Master Agreements related to Measure G-2010 projects (in alphabetical order):
BKF Engineers
CSW/Stuber-Stroeh Engineering Group
Nolte Vertical Five
Sandis
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of Master Agreements to the identified firms.
	 
Landscape Architecture Master Agreements for Measure G-2010 Projects
In November, 2011 the Board approved an update to the San Jose City College and the Evergreen Valley College Master Plan that identified projects that will require direct contracting to civil engineers.  In keeping with the updated Master Plan, the District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Landscape Architecture Services to perform various tasks under direct contract to the District on a work-order basis for various Measure G-2010 projects.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone, however the response was limited.
	 
On February 16, 2012, the District received a Statement of Qualifications (SOQ) from ten (10) firms in response to the RFQ.  A District Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District and each college reviewed each SOQ.  The panel members were Carlos Marques (Purchasing), Gail Mathis (Facilities), Greg Nelson and Joe Andrade (SJCC) and Henry Gee and Ron Sudweeks(EVC).  The Panel discussed the SOQ’s received and ranked the firms.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected four (4) firms to be offered Master Agreements related to Measure G-2010 projects (in alphabetical order):
Bellinger Foster Steinmetz
Joni L. Janeki & Associates  (Woman-owned Business)
LPAS Architecture Design  (Small Business)
Meyer Silberberg Land Architects  (Small Business)
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of Master Agreements to the identified firms.
	 
Project Authorization Amendment to Aedis Architecture
As part of the renovation of the Evergreen Valley College Central Energy Plant (CEP) and Police offices, it is necessary to relocate the Police operations to temporary “Swing Space” during the construction.  Further, a portion of the same cluster of temporary buildings will be relocated to provide EVC Program Management offices for Gilbane, and still others may be affected by the need to relocate them.
  
As the architect for the CEP/Police Renovation, Aedis is the most informed of the needs of the Police operations during the interim and have experience providing temporary police operations projects.  Further, the temporary buildings that will be utilized are a cluster of buildings on the EVC campus, so by extension Aedis is asked to provide programming related to the relocation and reuse of the additional buildings as well.
	 
As an extension of the design contract for the CEP/Police project, the Board is asked to approve the attached Project Authorization Amendment in the amount of Eighty-Two Thousand Three Hundred Ten Dollars ($82,310) to Aedis Architecture for programming and design services related to temporary building relocation.
Change Orders
Gilbane Time Extension to PM/CM Contract
On May 19, 2011 the Board authorized a contract to Gilbane Building Company to provide program and construction management services related to Measure G-2010.  The term of the contract was for one year from date of award, or May 18, 2012.  Due to the process of assigned tasks (update to college master plans, revisions to bond list projects, etc.) Gilbane has funds remaining within their contract.
	 
As such, and in order to align the contract for program & construction management services related to Measure G-2010 with the fiscal year, the Board is requested to approve a no-cost time extension change order to June 30, 2012 for the Gilbane program and construction management contract.
	 
In April / May the Board will be presented with the next phase of the PM/CM contract for Measure G-2010, for services for fiscal year July 2012 through June 2013.
	 
Attachments:
Measure G-2010 Summary Report
Measure G-2010 Monthly Report
Master Agreement (Civil) - BKF Engineers
Master Agreement (Civil) - CSW/Stuber-Stroeh Engineering Group
Master Agreement (Civil) - Nolte Vertical Five
Master Agreement (Civil) - Sandis
Master Agreement (Landscape) - Bellinger Foster Steinmetz
Master Agreement (Landscape) - Joni L. Janecki & Associates
Master Agreement (Landscape) - LPAS Architecture Design
Master Agreement (Landscape) - Meyer Silberberg Land Architects
Project Authorization - Aedis Architecture - Amendment #2

items.item_details: The San Jose Evergreen Community College District Foundation established by the Board of Trustees has begun to build a platform upon which to enhance the district's image and strengthen critical resource development avenues. On an annual basis, the Foundation reports on its fiscal and programmatic activities.  Since the last report to the Board of Trustees, the Foundation has accomplished many of its 2011 goals and has established new goals for 2012 which will further the foundation’s purpose of on-going support to both campuses.  The Foundation Chair and Director will provide information on both the 2011 and 2012 goals.

items.item_details:
2012-2013 Reopener Contract Sunshine Proposal
Faculty Association, AFT 6157 Opening Proposal
March 13, 2012
	 
The following represents the opening proposal from the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 (Union) to the District. The Union reserves the right to add, amend, delete or change any of these proposals. Bold underline is new language, cross out is language to be deleted.
	 
Article 8 Full-Time Salary, Hire Dates and Seniority Number      
	 
8.2.3    Full Time Faculty Working Less than 100%:  A faculty member with return rights to a permanent contract position, who teaches 60% 50% or more, but less than a full load 100% (FTE) shall receive the pro-rata salary listed in Appendices C 1 or C 2 and shall receive fully paid employee benefits and shall share the pro-rata cost of their eligible dependents' benefits (see Article 17). 
8.2.4   Adjunct Faculty Working More than 67%: Academic Adjunct faculty working more than 67% shall be paid on the full time salary schedule based on their load. Adjunct faculty working more than 67% shall receive fully paid employee benefits and shall share the pro-rata cost of their eligible dependent’s benefits (See Article 17). receive pro-rata salary and benefits for a given semester as described above only when their assigned load is more than 67%for that semester.
	 
New Section:
8.2.5  Full Time Temporary Faculty – shall receive all the benefits of the contract and shall be placed on the full time salary schedule for the duration of the assignment.
	 
	 
8.4       INITIAL CLASS PLACEMENT OF DISCIPLINES REQUIRING A MASTERS DEGREE
	 
Class placement at time of employment is based on the following determining factors:  A faculty member is placed in Classes II through VI depending upon degrees and number of academic units over and above degree(s).  Work experience does not determine class placement.
Also include these changes in Article 8.5
	 
NEW:  Faculty within the District who were categorical non-tenured faculty and were hired without a break in service into a full time position or adjunct position shall maintain their current class placement.  
NEW: Faculty who were adjunct faculty and were hired without a break in service into a full time position or categorical non-tenured position shall maintain their current class placement.
NEW:  Step Placement shall be according to Article 8.6 and 9.6
	 
1 Modifications were made to the 2001/02 salary schedule. Steps 1 through 5 of the schedule were eliminated. The faculty salary schedule was renumbered. Faculty at steps 1 through 5 were moved to step 6, and step 6 became step 1 on the renumbered schedule. A new step 17 was added for column IV. This step has the same conditions applied to the old step 22 for columns V and VI. A new step 19 was added for columns V and VI. 
	 
Class II – Master’s Degree
Class III – BA+45 Units w/MA
Class IV – BA+60 Units w/MA
Class V – BA+81 Units w/MA
Class VI – Doctorate
	           
8.6 NEW:  Original Step Placement: Delete Sections 8.6.1-8.6.5 and add following:
	 
Minimum/Maximum Step Placement-A newly appointed faculty member who has not had previous teaching experience and/ or verified occupational/vocational experience shall be placed on Step 1. Step 4 will be the highest step placement for newly appointed faculty members who present evidence of appropriate previous experience within the 60-day limit as defined in 8.4.3.  (Delete current Articles 8.6)
	 
Faculty members shall be placed on the salary schedule step based on their years of education service and occupational vocation experience
	 
8.6.1      Teaching Experience Placement 
For instructional experience and non-instructional experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university, faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-3 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 2       4 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 3       5 years previous teaching/non- instructional
Step 4       6 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
	 
8.6.2    Full-time Education Service Experience
For step placement, year-for-year credit will be allowed on the basis of one (1) increment for each year of verified experience as teacher, counselor, librarian, nurse or other faculty position experience not to exceed the equivalent of step 4.  A year experience is obtained by paid full-time educational service in an accredited secondary school or college or university. One (1) year of full-time teaching experience shall be defined as service rendered of no less than 75% of time and load during each semester of a previous qualifying school year. Employment as a teaching assistant or laboratory assistant will not be accepted as qualifying experience.  Teaching experience must be as “the teacher of record”.
	 
8.6.3    Credit of Previous Academic Adjunct Teaching Experience
Credit for academic adjunct paid-teaching experience shall be granted pro-rata based on the total teaching load taught by an instructor in the faculty member’s previous employment at an accredited secondary school, college or university.  The total credit allotted for previous academic adjunct experience will be rounded off to the nearest whole number.  An instructor may not be credited with more than one (1) year experience for service within any one (1)-school fiscal year.
	 
	 
8.6.4      Verified Occupational/Vocational Placement
For verified occupational/vocational experience faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-4 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 2       5-6 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 3       7-8 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 4       9 or more full time years of occupational work experience
	 
8.6.5      Credit for Prior Teaching and Creditable Work Experience
	 
8.6.5.1       Creditable Service
For placement, creditable service can include a combination of teaching experience and directly related work-experience not to exceed placement on Step 4.  Faculty shall be given credit to a maximum of six (6) equivalent years prior teaching, non instructional counseling, librarian experience outside the District (placing the faculty at Step 4) for teaching experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university. Faculty shall be given credit up to a maximum of six (6) years of creditable work experience (placing faculty at Step 4). 
	 
8.6.5.2       Combination of Teaching and Creditable Work Experience
Faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows for verified creditable work experience and teaching experience:
	 
Step 1       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal 0-3 years
Step 2       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 4 years
Step 3       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 5 years
Step 4       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 6 years or more
	 
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes
	 
Adjunct Faculty members employed for adjunct service shall be placed on the adjunct salary schedule step based on their years of education service and occupational vocation experience
	 
9.6.1      Teaching Experience Placement 
For teaching experience adjunct faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-3 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 2       4 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 3       5 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 4       6 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
	 
9.6.2    Verified Occupational/Vocational Placement
For verified occupational/vocational experience adjunct faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1     0-4 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 2     5-6 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 3     7-8 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 4     9 or more full time years of occupational work experience
	 
9.6.3      Credit for Prior Teaching/Non Instructional and Creditable Work Experience
	 
9.6.3.1       Creditable Service
For placement, creditable service can include a combination of teaching/non- instructional experience and directly related work-experience not to exceed placement on Step 4.  Adjunct faculty shall be given credit to a maximum of five (5) equivalent years prior teaching, non instructional counseling, librarian experience outside the District (placing the faculty at Step 3) for teaching experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university.   Adjunct Faculty shall be given credit to a maximum of six (6) equivalent years prior teaching, non instructional counseling, librarian experience outside the District (placing the faculty at Step 4) for teaching experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university. Faculty shall be given credit up to a maximum of six (6) years of creditable work experience (placing faculty at Step 4).
	 
	 
9.6.3.2       Combination of Teaching and Creditable Work Experience
Adjunct faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows for verified creditable work experience and teaching experience:
	 
Step 1       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal 0-3 years
Step 2       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 4 years
Step 3       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 5 years
Step 4       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 6 years or more
	 
Article 9.13 Credit for Prior Teaching AND WORK Experience  Delete Section
	 
Instructors shall be given credit to a maximum of five (5) equivalent years prior teaching experience outside the District for teaching experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university or up to a maximum of six (6) years of creditable work experience. 
	 
Article 9.16 Disbursement of Salary Checks to Adjunct Faculty (NEW)
Effective Fall 2012 adjunct faculty shall be paid 10 times a year on the tenth (10th) of the month in equal payments in these months:  September, October, November, December and January for fall semester; and February, March, April, May and June for spring semester.  The following conditions shall exist for this disbursement of these 10 checks per year:
9.16.1-NEED LANGUAGE WE AGREE ON
	 
Article 9.18.3.3 Attaining SRP Add bullet at end
In the event that full time categorical non tenured faculty members and temporary full time faculty become adjunct faculty, their teaching/non instructional experience shall be applied to attaining SRP at 40%.
If they have three (3) consecutive semesters and positive evaluations (Article 9.18.3.1) they will have SRP at 40%
With less than 3 consecutive semesters, they will be in the process of attaining SRP with the number of semesters they have already completed.
	 
9.18.4.3 SRP is withdrawn if the adjunct faculty member does not work the SRP load in any semester except for the following reason:
Add following Bullets at end:
The adjunct faculty member requests not to receive an assignment in a division because the adjunct faculty member has accepted a conflicting assignment in another college or university provided the request is in writing and accompanied by proof of the conflicting assignment
Other extenuating personal circumstances which the adjunct faculty member and the dean mutually agree make acceptance or commencement of the assignment impossible.
	 
Article 9.18.5     Award of Seniority Rehire Preference: When an adjunct faculty member has successfully achieved SRP they shall receive a letter in the mail from the Office of Academic Support (SJCC) or the Office of Academic Services (EVC) informing them of their new Seniority Rehire status and including reference to Article 9.18 and to the need of adjunct to maintain their 33%/40% load in order to keep their SRP.
	 
9.22.3    The District will provide health benefits to adjunct faculty under the Kaiser Plan offered to full time Faculty (employee only) allowed under Ed. Code Sec. 87861 as follows:
	 
	 
NEW Article: Implementation of State Disability Insurance:
State Disability Insurance (SDI): Participation in the plan is mandatory. Adjunct Faculty payroll deductions will be made to cover the cost of participation effective March 10, 2012.
Faculty participating in State Disability shall upon their request be able to integrate their sick leave into their SDI benefits.
The Union and District will work together to develop language for this integration prior to June 30, 2012.
	 
Article 11 Calendars-Need calendar for 2014-2015
	 
Article 13 Leaves of Absence –article of Choice
                Article 13.21 Catastrophic Leave
13.21.2      Basic Provisions
The following provisions apply to the catastrophic illness leave (CIL) bank available to faculty.
	 
13.21.2.1          Any faculty member with a balance of eligible sick leave credits of twenty five (25) days or more after such donation may donate days to the bank, up to but not more than fifteen (15) days per year.
13.21.2.2          Faculty members who donate at least one day per academic year shall be entitled to request catastrophic leave for their own personal use.  Tenure-track faculty members shall not be required to donate one day of sick leave until they are tenured.
	 
13.21.2.3          Any faculty member may receive leave credits from the bank when approved in accordance with the required provisions.
	 
13.21.2.4          There will be no attempt to evaluate a day donated or received on the basis of the pay rate of the donor or the recipient.
	 
13.21.4      Establishing the Bank and Collecting Deposits
	 
13.21.4.1          There will be an initial call from the office of Human Resources/and or the Union for donations to establish the bank.
	 
13.21.4.2          There will be an annual call for donations, unless the bank has more than ninety (90) days.
	 
13.21.4.3          There will be calls for donations when the bank balance falls below forty five (45) days. Payroll Services will notify Human Resource Services when the balance falls below forty five (45) days, at which time Human Resources and/or the Union will send out the call for donations.
	 
13.21.4.4          Donations from those eligible to donate will only be accepted during official calls from Human Resources/and or the Union.  The Union may determine to suspend the call for donations when the bank reaches a sufficient number of sick leave days.          
	 
Article 17 Benefits
The District shall continue to pay the full cost of any increases in all health and welfare benefits. There will be no monetary Cap on medical benefits listed in the contract to ensure comparable benefits with the other bargaining unit.
	 
	 
Article 18 Retirement
The District shall continue to pay the full cost of any increases in all health benefits for retirees. There will be no monetary Cap on medical benefits listed in the contract to ensure comparable benefits with the other bargaining unit.
	 
Evaluation of Faculty 2nd article of choice Articles 19 and Article 19A
	 
Article 19  Adjunct Evaluations: 19.5.2/19.6.1/19.7.1 Delete words:   At least
Article 19A  Evaluation of FT Temporary…  19.5.1  Delete Words:  At least
items.item_text: Presentation of the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 Contract Reopener Proposal with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District for 2012-2013
items.item_text_raw: 5. Presentation of the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 Contract Reopener Proposal with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District for 2012-2013

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District presents their reopener proposal with the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 for 2012-2013.  The District request that issues in the following articles be negotiated for 2012-2013.
	 
Article 4.9 & 5.3 – Parking 
Eliminate Free Parking
	 
Article 8 – Salary
Seeking concessions to address budget shortfall
	 
Article 9.15 – Office Hours
Clarify language as to adjunct member’s posting of time & place of office hours.   
         
Article 9.18 – Seniority Rehire Rights
To be earned in a discipline
	 
Additional language clarifying and defining withholding and withdrawing of SRP
	 
Article 12.5 – Faculty Professional Responsibility
Language defining specific faculty professional responsibilities
	 
Article 17 – Benefits 
Seeking concessions to address budget shortfall
	 
	 
	 
The District reserves the right to add, amend, delete and/or change any of these proposals.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present the District's contract reopener proposal for 2012-2013, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the April 10, 2012 Board meeting.
items.item_text: Presentation of the San Jose Evergreen Community College District's Contract Reopener Proposal with the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 for 2012-2013
items.item_text_raw: 6. Presentation of the San Jose Evergreen Community College District's Contract Reopener Proposal with the Faculty Association, AFT 6157 for 2012-2013

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District presents their reopener proposal with The California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 for 2012-2013.  The District request that issues in the following articles be negotiated for 2012-2013.
	 
Article 6 – Salary
Seeking concessions to address budget shortfall
	 
Article 7 – Benefits
Seeking concessions to address budget shortfall
	 
Article 8.6 – Call Back Time 
Clarifying language regarding definition of call back time
	 
Article 19 – Disciplinary Action
Provide better language to articulate each step in progressive discipline
	 
Article 20 – Professional Growth
Add language addressing application for professional growth
	 
Article 23 – Reclassification
Expand article to include working-out-of class provisions
	 
	 
The District reserves the right to add, amend, delete and/or change any of these proposals.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present the District's contract reopener proposal for 2012-2013, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the April 10, 2012 Board meeting.
